heisig_chinese_memo: If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one.
heisig_story: Here we see a pictograph of a tree, showing the main trunk in the long vertical stroke and the boughs in the long horizontal stroke. The final two strokes sweep down in both directions to indicate the roots. Although it may look similar at first sight to the kanji for water (Frame 137), the order in which it is written is completely different and this affects its final appearance.

origin_of_ch_char_book: The monument features the three supreme existences of the Universe: Heaven (å¤©), Earth(åœ°), and Human (äºº)â€” and the five basic elements of the universe: water(æ°´), fire(ç«), iron (é‡‘), wood(æœ¨), soil(åœŸ) (14th-19th century) ,A man sitting cross-legged (1915) After walking and running, one would feel tired and thirsty and want to rest under the cool shade of a tree. (ä¼‘, xiu=hsiu, rest) is the description of a person (äºº, ren, human) resting under a tree (æœ¨, mu, tree).,The ancient Chinese considered that there were five essential elements in the universe: Water (æ°´, shui), Fire (ç«, huo), Wood (æœ¨, mu), Iron (é‡‘, jin), and Earth (åœŸ, tu). The five main elements interact and create each other or restrain each other. For example, the tree burns and creates fire which burns down to ashes and becomes earth (soil). Water restrains fire and fire can melt metal. (äº”, wu, five) contains such philosophical meanings. The top line means sky , the bottom line is earth , and the middle shows how the â€œfive elementsâ€ cross and interact with each other.,This axe is also a part of another word (æ–°, xin=hsin, new). This word has a pointy blade and a tree (æœ¨, mu, tree) beneath it, and an axe cutting the tree (æ–¤, jin, a unit of weight). Something cut by an axe roughly was an unit of weight before, and now this unit is used as an important unit of weight (500g).
